text: Molecular basis of a multiple lymphokine deficiency in a patient with severe combined immunodeficiency .

We have previously reported that the T lymphocytes of a child with severe combined immunodeficiency are defective in the transcription of several lymphokine genes that include <extra_id_0> IL2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> IL5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which encode <extra_id_0> interleukins 2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> 3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> 4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> 5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> -3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> -4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> -5 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .

text: To determine whether the defect in the patient 's T lymphocytes involved a trans - acting factor common to the affected lymphokine genes , we examined the ability of nuclear factors from the patient 's T lymphocytes to bind response elements present in the regulatory region of <extra_id_0> IL2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
Nuclear factor NF-kB , activation protein 1 ( AP-1 ) , <extra_id_0> OCT-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and NF-IL-2B binding activity were normal .

In contrast , the binding of the nuclear factor of activated T cells ( NF-AT ) to its response element in the <extra_id_0> IL2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> enhancer and to an NF-AT-like response element present in the <extra_id_0> IL4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> enhancer was abnormal .

text: These results indicate that an abnormality of / or influencing NF-AT may underlie the multiple lymphokine deficiency in this patient .
